sentence.idiomatic: College students these days understand only a smattering of China's profound culture.
Buddhist scriptures are very profound. Even after copying them a thousand times, you might not necessarily grasp them.
His theory is very profound. For has been considered a classic for one hundred thousand years.
When I first arrived in Shanghai, I was a fish out of water. I got a lot of pimples on my face.
It's not a big deal to have difficulty acclimating to a new environment. When you get used to the new environment it's fine.
When famous foreign brands enter the Chinese market, they often have difficulty adapting. They need to be adjusted.
If you want to go study abroad, then just go. I won't hold you back.
When the kid took the test this time, his other subjects were fine, it was just his English holding him back.
During the relay race he carelessly dropped the baton and held everyone back.
Many people don't know classical allusions. They often misinterpret the meaning of Chinese idioms.
Giving substantial rewards and recognition to Olympic gold medalists is actually a misinterpretation of the spirit of the Olympics.
Malicious misinterpret the law to avoid responsibility and you will necessarily be severely punished.
There are too many fraudsters, and their schemes are very clever. It's simply impossible to defend against them.
It's impossible to defend against computer viruses. Installing anti-virus software doesn't work really well.
There's too much seduction these days. It's impossible to defend against betrayal in a marriage.
This group of people is good at doing parodies. They put things people have said on pictures of animals. It's hilarious.
When you make fun of historical figures in a history play, it's easy to mislead the audience.
In an age of parody, it's very hard to attract people's attention if you don't have something fresh.
If a good product gets a good name, you can safely say that it's already halfway there. Coca Cola and Mercedes Benz are some extremely good examples.

word.literal: and to this must be added

sentence.idiomatic: But Chinese is very profound. When you add in the different dialects and cultural factors, some foreign goods' Chinese names are really out of place in China.
No matter how good a product is, if consumers interpret its name in a ridiculous way, it will definitely be hobbled. The auto industry is full of examples of this.
Think of a name like ``Rong Wei" for a sedan. It seems very respectable, but it sounds very much like ``Wrong Way." You can imagine the effect of this brand name.
Then there's the Japanese car called ``Suzuki," which sounds in Chinese like the word for a tomb where you bury the dead. No wonder Chinese people consider it unlucky!

Lately there's another hot topic-- the Korean National TV station SBS. These three letters stand for the English abbreviation Seoul Broadcasting System. But they make Chinese people think of a filthy word.

Not only foreign enterprises have their product names distorted. It's hard for domestic enterprises to prevent, too. For instance, there's a kind of medicine called ``Sidashu," which sounds in Chinese like ``Four Big Uncles." Afterwards, the company just made a joke of it- in their advertisement, they had roles for Four Big Uncles.
In an age of parody, be careful when you come up with a name!
